title: 100% calculus or 100% graph
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large \\frac{x^n-1}{x-1} = a"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If there exists a "},{"type":"text","text":"real number","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that the above equation is true for an "},{"type":"text","text":"even integer n","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":", then is it true that there is "},{"type":"text","text":"only one","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that satisfies the same equation?"}]}]}

title: 100 candles problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" candles which are numbered from 1 to 100.There are 100 students.
The 1st student lights up all the candles.
The 2nd student changes the state of the candles(lights up or lights off) which are multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
The 3rd student changes the state of the candles(lights up or lights off) which are  multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/C4DbhiSr1x-download.jpeg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This continues till the 100th student."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find how many candles are still lightened up in the end."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is same as "How many numbers from 1 to 100 has odd amount of positive divisors?""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"All perfect squares has odd amount of positive divisors,so the answer is 1,4,9,...,100,total of 10 candles."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Before tackling the problem lets lay down some facts,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If a candle which is lighted off it needs to have an even amount of factors*"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(explanation: because the lighting and lighting off cancel each other out)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*Factors is in regard to the candle number"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, a candle which is lighted on needs to have an odd number of factors*"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we can list down the numbers which numbers have an odd number of factors.**   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"** There is a faster but similar way"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Before we list off to 100, we can just list off to 20.
The reason being is that we need the pattern not a hardworking trial and error machine."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<--  Pause (do it on your own before i reveal the answer)-->"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OK. The odd-number-factor numbers should be 1,4,9,16
We can now get the ah-ha moment. All of the numbers are perfect squares.
So, we happily write down the perfect squares from 1 to 100 and count them."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But there is an even faster way!
Simply take the square root of 100 which is 10 and Voila. ( In the case of an irrational number just take the [whole number] quotient.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: dark coin riddle

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I have to say, the "Is it possible to split the pile of coins in to two equal parts(...)" has completely misled me into thinking the piles had to have the same amount of coins..

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The question asks to split the pile of 100 coins into two parts/piles. And to clear any confusion, when I say two equal piles, I mean to say two piles that have the same amount of gold faces facing up, and do not mean two piles with the same number of coins."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You can only use this method if you know how many gold faces are facing up ways in the pile of 100 coins, and in this problem, we have 20 gold faces facing up. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your first step will be to take "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"any"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" 20 coins from the pile of 100 coins, so that you have a pile of 20 coins, and 80 coins."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your second step will be to flip all the coins in the pile of 20 coins. This will give you 2 piles that consist of the same amount of gold faces facing up.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I will prove that this works for any scenario, using algebra. Say "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the amount of coins in the pile of 80 coins, than there will be 20 - "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" coins in the pile consisting of 20 coins. If we substitute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for 13, we get 13 gold faces facing up ways coins in the pile of 80 coins, and 20 - 13 = 7 gold faces facing up ways coins in the pile of 20 coins. 13 + 7 = 20 , and when you flip the pile consisting of 20 coins, the 7 gold faces facing up will become silver faces facing up, and the 13 silver faces facing up will become 13 gold faces facing up ways coins. 13 = 13 , hence two piles consisting of the same amount of gold faces facing up.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            How do we get two equal halves using this method? As I understood it, we had to split the coins into two equal parts, and then make sure each half had the same number of gold coins facing up.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Divide the 100 coins into two piles of 20 coins and 80 coins each. If the first pile has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gold, it has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" silver. The second pile will have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gold and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"60+x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" silver."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, if you flip all of the coins in one pile, you swap the number of gold and silver in the pile. So, if you flip the first pile, it will have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20-x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gold and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" silver. The number of gold in both piles is now the same."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Get 20 coins and flip them. This will be your second pile."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let X be the coins you flipped are originally gold (face). The number of coins on the first pile facing gold side will be reduced by X. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20 - X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
Among the 20 coins you placed in the second pile, there will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20 - X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" coins originally facing silver side. After flipping the coins, those silver side will become gold side."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 Consecutive Numbers

Determine the last two digits of the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}^{8}+a_{2}^{8}+...+a_{100}^{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You should explain that we have to multiply the decimal part with 7 to get the exact answer (1.4 day). If it was 101 days, the division would make 14.42857, I'm afraid people are going to think that the answer was 4 days; even worse, 5 days.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Basically, you have numbers starting from 0."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0-Mon"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1-Tue"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2-Wed"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3-Thur"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4-Fri"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5-Sat"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6-Sun"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7-Mon"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You can either count up from sevens until you get to the number thats the highest before 100 or you can do 100 divided by seven, with a remainder of 2. The answer is 98. You know that 98 is a Monday because when you count up by sevens, every number that you count on will be a Monday. However, 98 is still not 100. You need to count up one day for every number."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"98-Mon"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"99-Tue"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100-Wed"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore Wednesday is the answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"if we divide 100 by 7,the remainder is 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"so Monday+2 days=wednesday"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"98 days later: Monday since 98 is divisible by 7 (98 divided by 7 = 14).
2 more days later: "},{"type":"text","text":"Wednesday","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" (the answer).
That's 100 days passed!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10.10=100 
Today is Monday and Monday+9days=Wednesday it means that 10days are passed 
Now 10days.10days=100days and it will be surely Wednesday"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In this case, we use modular addition, as so: 
If we begin at Monday, and we fast forward 100 days, we must divide the amount of days we are "fast-forwarding" by the total number of days in a week, which is 7. We get a remainder of 2, which is the amount of days we go forward from Monday from. 2 days after Monday is "},{"type":"text","text":"Wednesday","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"After seven days have passed, it will be Monday again. So, we want to divide 100 by 7 and take the remainder."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 mod 7 = 2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means that 100 days from Monday is the same as two days from Monday. Therefore it will be Wednesday."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7 days in a week therefore 98th day would be MONDAY.
Add 2 days to it ie Wednesday."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know if today is monday after a week it will also be monday... so let see how many weeks contain 100 days...
100days=14weeks+2days
means in 14weeks it will be monday + 2days
so after 
100 days it will be wednesday..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 % 7 = 2 (NOTE THAT % MEANS MODULUS, NOT DIVISION).
Monday + 2 = Wednesday."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since, in a week we have 7 days
so for 98 days it takes 1 weeks, Now remaining two days are 99-tuesday and finally 100th day will be wednesday."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Integral Solutions!
body:

"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle{A=\left\{ 1,2,3,5,6,10,15,30 \right\} }"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For set "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find the number of positive integral solution of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (x,y,z) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that satisfy the condition "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy z \in a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Too easy? Try this problem."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"is there a better way than to observe that all numbers must be powers of 2 and 5 and 3 and their products,
 from which 1 comes in one way , 2,3,5 in 3 ways each,  6,10,15 in 9 ways each(products of two taken at a time) and 30 in 27 ways (product of all 3) so total 64"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

Let  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\xyzt=2*3*5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  where x,y,z are 3 "},{"type":"text","text":"Real beggars","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  and  't' is "},{"type":"text","text":"false beggar","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" , 
So you have 3 different books (2,3,5)  which can be distributed in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways 
where  1st Book (say 2) has 4 options 
2nd Book (say 3) has 4 options 
3rd Book (say 5) has 4 options "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So total ways are = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4*4*4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes, there is. This deserves to be a solution but I unfortunately lost my attempts:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clearly, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the set of divisors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30 = 2 \times 3 \times 5 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, take three boxes: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x, y, z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For each of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2,3,5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", you have four choices: To put it in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", to put it in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", to put it in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", to put it throw it away."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, there are a total of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to do the things.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100 Days streak problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/15db28163e.56ed620179.FqmXaC.jpg?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nIf 100 identical dices are rolled then the_number of different outcomes of the numbers appearing on the dice are?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{k}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represent the number of dice that show the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Then we need to find the number of non-negative integer solutions to the equation"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1} + a_{2} + a_{3} + a_{4} + a_{5} + a_{6} = 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \le a_{k} \le 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \le k \le 6."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is a now a "},{"type":"text","text":"stars and bars","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" problem, which according to Theorem two in this link has the solution"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dbinom{100 + 6 - 1}{100} = \dbinom{105}{100} = \boxed{96560646}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Nihar Mahajan – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Congrats! I once got a 10,100 day streak. Oh, by the way, that's in binary (20). In binary, you'd have a 1,100,100 - a 1.1 million day streak! "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Congrats! "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Tanishq Varshney"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/tanishq-6o8s0m/"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  Keep the streak alive!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Thank you sir "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ddot \smile"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Tanishq Varshney"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/tanishq-6o8s0m/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Nice problem, and congrats on the streak. :)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Trevor Arashiro – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" You're welcome. That is a really good paper; I've bookmarked it for future reference. Partitions show up everywhere, (just like "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\phi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"); I just learned about "},{"type":"text","text":"Bell numbers","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" last week and have started to realize how significant they are. The more you know ..... :) "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Ok, wow, I thought there might have been something simple like stars and bars but guess not lol.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That's quite the interesting paper.  It was a lot of fun to read through and I learned A LOT.  Thanks for showing it to me :)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            If I understand correctly, I think we would be looking at the partitions of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of size "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Looking at a simpler version, say "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1} + a_{2} + a_{3} + a_{4} = 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{i}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s are non-negative and non-distinct, we would have solution quadruplets"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(5,0,0,0), (4,1,0,0), (3,2,0,0), (3,1,1,0), (2,2,1,0), (2,1,1,1)."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We could label this as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(n;k)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the number of partitions of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" into at most "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" parts. In this case we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(5;4) = 6."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"text","text":"Here","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is the OEIS listing; there are some formulas but they're pretty scary, and the listing only goes up to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"55."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" However, that's the general idea. :) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Edit: "},{"type":"text","text":"Here","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is a good paper that I think addresses the matter at hand.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Is there a theorem that can be used if the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" aren't distinct?  I know that for this problem, if the dice were distinct then the number of ways would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6^{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  But if you're trying to find the number of non-distinct ordered pairs "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":")a_1,a_2,a_3,a_4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_1+a_2+a_3+a_4=100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". What would you do then?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100 Days Streak problem!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\Delta ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AB=AC=10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Plot "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" distinct points on the side "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".Define "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_i =AP_i^2+P_iB . P_iC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , then find the value of "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\Large \\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/qzi7Lc2LEF-12.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Construction :","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AD \perp BC "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the triangle is isosceles , "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BD = DC=x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"DP_i=x_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_i =AP_i^2+P_iB . P_iC \\  \Rightarrow a_i =AP_i^2+(x-x_i)(x+x_i) \\ \Rightarrow a_i =AP_i^2-x_i^2+x^2 \\ \Rightarrow a_i =AD^2+x^2 \dots \text{(Pythagoras Theorem for}1\leq i \leq 100) \\ \Rightarrow a_i = AB^2 = (10)^2 = 100 \\ \Rightarrow\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_i = \Large\boxed{10000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using Stewart's Theorem, we get:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_{i}C 10^2 + P_{i}B 10^2 = BC(AP_{i} + P_{i}B . P_{i}C)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100(P_{i}B +P_{i}C) = BC(AP_{i} + P_{i}B . P_{i}C)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(AP_{i} + P_{i}B . P_{i}C) = a_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100(P_{i}B +P_{i}C) = BC . a_{i}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Consider that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_{i} B + P_{i}C = BC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100(P_{i}B +P_{i}C) = BC . a_{i}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100BC=BC . a_{i}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC \neq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then it can be crossed out. Thus, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_i =100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
for any integers of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{i=1}^{100} a_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{i=1}^{100} 100 = 100*100=10000"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since there are no restrictions in the question, let us consider all the 100 points at B and infinitesimally close to B. In this case "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" P_i B "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can  be considered as an infinitesimally small value, rounded off to 0. 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_i\ = \sum_{i=1}^{100}(AP_i^2 +P_iB.P_iC)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Since the points are at B, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" AP_i=AB=10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sum_{i=1}^{100} a_i\ = \sum_{i=1}^{100}AB^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" = \sum_{i=1}^{100}100"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \boxed{100000} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 days streak special

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow A = \phi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"    "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow n(A) = 0  \quad \quad  \quad[ \text{n(A) denotes number of elements in A ] }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"    "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow n(P(A)) = 2^n = 2^0 = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow n(P(P(A))) = 2^1 = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow n(P(P(P(A)))) = 2^2 = 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"    "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow n(P(P(P(P(A))))) = 2^4 = 16"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow n(P(P(P(P(P(A)))))) = \boxed{2^{16}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Bhaiya, edit from your 3rd implication onwards. For example, in 3rd implication, I think you meant n(P(A)) = 1, because P(A) = 1 when A is empty makes no sense. Include cardinality function every time you are calculating the number of elements in power set, not the power set itself.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 100-day streak!

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The terms of Fibonacci sequence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\forall k \in \mathbb{N}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are defined as:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_1 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_2=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_{k+1} = F_k + F_{k-1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k\ge 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \lim_{k \to \infty} {\dfrac {F_{k+1}}{F_k}} = \phi "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(100, \ln{\phi}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(n, a) = \dfrac {\cosh{[(n+1)a]}-\cosh{[(n-1)a]}}{\sinh{(na)}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n, a \in \mathbb{R} - \{0\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} \phi & = \displaystyle \lim_{k \to \infty} {\dfrac {F_{k+1}}{F_k}} = \lim_{k \to \infty} {\dfrac {F_{k}+F_{k-1}}{F_k}} = \lim_{k \to \infty} {\left( 1 + \dfrac {F_{k-1}}{F_k}  \right)} \\ & =  1 + \displaystyle \lim_{k \to \infty} {\dfrac {F_{k-1}}{F_k}} = 1 + \dfrac {1}{\phi} \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow \phi = 1 + \dfrac {1}{\phi} \quad \Rightarrow \phi^2 - \phi - 1 = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \phi = \dfrac {1+\sqrt{5}}{2} =  \varphi \text{, golden ratio}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} f(100, \ln{\varphi}) & = \dfrac {\cosh{(101\ln{\varphi})}-\cosh{(99\ln{\varphi})}}{\sinh{(100\ln{\varphi})}} \\ & =  \dfrac {\frac {1}{2} \left( e^{101\ln{\varphi}}+e^{-101\ln{\varphi}}-e^{99\ln{\varphi}} -e^{-99\ln{\varphi}}\right)}{\frac {1}{2} \left( e^{101\ln{\varphi}}-e^{-100\ln{\varphi}} \right)}  \\ & =  \dfrac {\varphi^{101}+\varphi^{-101}-\varphi^{99}-\varphi^{-99}}{\varphi^{100}-\varphi^{-100}} \\ & =  \dfrac {\varphi^{100} \left( \varphi-\varphi^{-1} \right) -\varphi^{-100} \left( \varphi-\varphi^{-1} \right)}{\varphi^{100}-\varphi^{-100}}  \\ & = \varphi - \dfrac {1}{\varphi} = \boxed{1} \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Dankeschön für der Vorschlag, "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Chew-Seong Cheong"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/chew-seong-872sn7/"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  c:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I was a little lazy to write it out as a limit and I typed it instead, hahaha."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I don't believe in the existence of any God, but I think this quote is beautiful from the viewpoint that it makes us a reminder of how mathematics have been developed and observed by us throughout the centuries."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I used the Binet's formula to arrive in the initial statement that this fraction would be valued as one, for "},{"type":"text","text":"n","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" different than zero. Plugging into exponential form of hyperbolic trigonometric functions is a good and easier way to find the value of this function.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"text","text":"Mikael Marcondes","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", denke für den Satz: "Die ganzen Zahlen hat der liebe Gott gemacht, alles andere ist Menschenwerk." Ich habe gelernt, ein bisschen Deutsch."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I only learned now that it is originally German.  I have suggested changes to the phrasing this problem.  Hope it is useful.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
